title: Court freezes Georgia's 6-week abortion ban
text:
A fetal heartbeat usually can be detected around six weeks of pregnancy. The law would impose criminal penalties including jail time for abortion providers and was set to take effect in January.

The law also conferred full legal rights on fetuses but did not give guidance on how to implement that change under Georgia laws, a provision those challenging the law argued was vague and could be enforced in arbitrary and discriminatory ways.

Kemp has not yet indicated if he will appeal the ruling but his spokesperson said in a statement Tuesday that his administration "will continue to fight for the unborn."

Many major Hollywood studios and other corporations that do business in Georgia threatened to take their business elsewhere if courts allowed the law to take effect. Netflix, Disney, AT&T’s WarnerMedia and Comcast’s NBCUniversal each threatened boycotts while other media giants also considered such moves. The state is a leading destination for film and TV production.

The abortion ban was part of a wave of action from GOP-controlled states emboldened by the Supreme Court's new conservative majority. One or more of the new laws could serve as a test case for the high court to reexamine and potentially overturn the constitutional right to an abortion under Roe vs. Wade.

This year alone, Alabama passed a near-total abortion ban; Kentucky, Mississippi, Louisiana, Ohio and Georgia passed six-week "heartbeat" bans; Missouri passed an eight-week ban; and Utah and Arkansas passed 18-week bans. None have taken effect. Federal judges have blocked the policies in Ohio, Mississippi, Kentucky, Missouri and Utah, and legal challenges are pending in the other states. The 5th Circuit Court of Appeals will hear arguments on Mississippi's 15-week abortion ban on Monday.
